title: Managing Stress with Crohn's

content: The constant stress and anxiety that come along with Crohn’s disease is multifaceted. You’re worried not only about what may happen because of it, but also about the painful symptoms that you’re having now. It’s a constant battle of trying to relieve your stress while not adding anxiety by thinking about the future.

For me, the hardest part about my Crohn’s diagnosis was losing control. I’ve always had control over every aspect of my life. I’ve taken a lot of pride in the fact that I’m independent and take care of things on my own. A lot of my inner peace and ability to push through hard times came from feeling like I was in charge of my fate in any circumstance.

When I was diagnosed with something as unpredictable as Crohn’s disease, I felt that sense of control be utterly ripped away. At that point there was not much I could do. I had to learn how to relieve stress and anxiety by some way other than taking control, which is all I’d ever known how to do.

content: Learning how to manage these feelings while living with Crohn’s disease took a lot of time and patience. I had to learn an entire new coping mechanism, because I was definitely not handling it well at the start.

In the first year of my diagnosis, I spent much of my time thinking that I could change my lifestyle, my diet – anything I could think of -- in order to “fix” the problem. I knew I couldn’t get rid of Crohn’s completely. But I thought maybe if I tried hard enough to eat the right things, get enough exercise, and stay as healthy as possible, I might be able to go into remission and never even know I had Crohn’s to begin with.

While I still strongly believe that lifestyle changes for Crohn’s are super important, I think the number one most important thing you can do is manage your stress and anxiety. For me, those have been the main things that trigger symptoms.

content: Now, instead of obsessing over how I can fix my Crohn’s, I prioritize doing the things that make me happy and that help me stop negative thoughts and behaviors. I try to do all the things that I love doing in order to remind myself that Crohn’s isn’t something that should limit my life experiences.

I try to constantly remind myself that the time I spend worrying about all the negative things that may or may not happen takes away from the time that I could be enjoying life. I make sure to take full advantage of the days that I feel good, something that has been a positive change since my Crohn’s diagnosis.

Planning ahead for things as much as possible still gives me a small sense of control. This is something that may work for you as well. It can be as simple as knowing what you’re going to eat when you go out to avoid any possible triggers. It could mean being sure to always bring extra medications so that you always have access to them.

content: But no matter how much you think you’ve planned ahead, something usually comes up that you’re not prepared for. And that’s OK -- you’ll get through it. I’ve found that letting go of the “what if” anxiety is truly freeing. As long as you can acknowledge this and believe that you’ll be fine, it becomes much easier to relieve a lot of that overwhelming stress.
